captions.text:
For those of you who for some reason are not
obsessed with the Fermi paradox, Enrico Fermi

posed the following – the same guy with
the nuclear reactor in Chicago and all that

– posed the following question. If there
are alien worlds as you might claim since

there are billions of stars in billions of
galaxies, you would expect billions of planets

and then you’d expect a few millions of
earth-like planets. Where, why haven’t we

heard from these other civilization? And the
answer I think is not that complicated. We’ve

only been listening for other civilizations
for 50 years, 70 years, it depends on how

you count. And you have to acknowledge that
civilizations have to emerge and be able to

communicate at the same time. When you have
something that’s been going on for 13.6

billion years there’s a lot of opportunities
to miss each other. So the Fermi paradox,

for me, is not a reason to give up and take
the black capsule and have no hope for humankind

because we are just this unique thing in the
middle of nowhere and will never amount to

anything. No. For me the Fermi paradox drives
us forward. Why haven’t we heard from anybody?

Because we’re not listening hard enough.
We’re not being diligent enough. We’re

not thinking it through well enough. So we
at the Planetary Society support the, of course

support the search for extraterrestrial intelligence
but the search for extraterrestrial intelligence

in the optical bandwidths in what you and
I call visible light.

And as you may know, NASA is doing these tests
using laser communication. In other words

instead of sending radio signals with wavelengths
the size of this room and so information packets

spread out over the size of this room, you’d
use light waves where the information packets

are just a few hundred billionths of a meter
long and so you can get a lot more – it’s

fiber optic. You get a lot more – the comparison
of fiber optic with traditional copper wire.

You get a lot more information, a lot more
bandwidth. So who knows, maybe the aliens

are sending us optical signals and we missed
the point. Come on. One way to be sure you

never hear from another civilization and realize
or validate Fermi’s paradox is to not listen.

So this to me is an obligation of a civilization,
of a civilized society is to prevent – is

to present or to allocate just a little of
our intellect and treasure to the search for

extraterrestrial life. Because there’s two
questions that get every one of us. Where

did we come from? Where did we come from?
And that’s, by the way, what the Rosetta

mission is working on. It’s going to a comet
which is part of the – seems to be and is

certainly part of the primordial solar system.
So by understanding that we’ll understand

more about where we all came from. And the
second question is are we alone? Could we

possibly be alone in the universe? And to
answer those questions you have to explore

space. That’s what we do at the Planetary
Society. Did I mention that? Planetary.org.
Did I bring us up? Thank you.

title: Bill Nye's Answer to the Fermi Paradox

This is not a particularly adequate and effective response to the Fermi 
Paradox.  The Fermi Paradox argues that there should be an abundance of 
clear evidence of colonization, or at least of visitation, by 
extra-terrestrial intelligence on earth by now, and there is not. At best, 
the evidence is scant and ambiguous. One implication of the paradox is that 
we should not even have to look that hard for such evidence as it should be 
overwhelming, and it is not. For myself, I do not know what to believe, but 
the Fermi Paradox, though not airtight, is difficult to argue against.﻿

comments.text:
+Carbosful I'm afraid your explanations are based on a number of 
assumptions as well, but more importantly they're missing the point. There 
have been many proposals aimed at invalidating Fermi's paradox, though none 
have been deemed completely satisfactory. The extreme age of the galaxy, 
and the huge number of potential birthing sites does make it strange that 
no civilization has left *any traces* of its existence. We're not talking 
about alien nanotechnology that could (easily) replicate across the galaxy, 
we're talking about anything that - at one stage or another - left 
something behind that could be recognized as 'artificial'. Mind you, I'm 
not saying that any of the explanations are wrong, but they're not 
satisfactory considering the apparent contradiction between high estimates 
of the probability of the existence of extraterrestrial civilization and no 
evidence for their existence.

comments.text:
Not a very good statement of Fermi's Paradox.

-There are billions of stars a billion years older than Sol.
-Even if Faster than Light travel is impossible, the time it would take to 
saturate a galaxy with colonies is at max around 10 million years, 
travelling at .1C.
-Therefore, even a single space faring civilization rising 10 million years 
ago, SHOULD HAVE ALREADY COLONIZED EARTH.

There is the further certainty of self-replicating automated or 
artificially intelligent probes that enter a system, set up an economy to 
produce more probes with space resources such as asteroids, and then 
immediately send seeds off to new stars.

There is a nearly 100% chance Earth has already been at least visited and 
some self-replicating infrastructure left behind. More importantly, there 
may be superluminal communication relays left behind.

But we see no evidence for any of this. Why not?

Does every civilization inevitably destroy itself?
Is every civilization being systematically erradicated?
Do civilizations leave the physical universe we know altogether?
Is the temptation of a self-indulgent personal virtual universe, where each 
person can exist like a god, too great for civilizations to resist?

There aren't very many possibilities.﻿

As usual we assume that the other 'out there' will be like us, as curious 
about others as we are, having bilateral symmetry, bipedalism, 
emotionality, etc.  "Intelligent" life becomes an ambiguous term.  Maybe 
the intelligent life form on, say, Europa will be akin to a social insect 
here, gaining its intelligence from interdependence.  Even on our own 
planet we make the same mistake of assuming that higher mammals such as 
orcas are like us, are smiling at us, appreciate our affections, want to be 
trained and entertain paying customers in a water park--until one attacks a 
trainer, reminding us how little interest they actually have in those 
flawed humans and how much they would rather be back in the ocean with 
their pods. 

Sure.  Let's keep looking out there to learn if we are truly alone or not.  
Our curiosity will drive us, just as it did Magellan, Balboa, et al.  But 
we might be wiser, in the meantime, to consider that humans have more in 
common with parasitoids than with the extraterrestrial alien of our 
imagination.  We've almost killed out host; time to find another. ﻿

comments.text:
This explanation assumes that we need to be listening in order to hear from 
other civilizations.

The question that remains is - why haven't other civilizations made the 
effort to reveal themselves to us?

Part of the assumption of the Fermi paradox is that it is likely that there 
are millions of other civilizations in existence that developed millions of 
years or even billions of years before us and have, therefore, reached far 
greater levels of development than we have. Accordingly, it is assumed that 
those civilizations 1) would have been searching for us for far longer than 
we have been searching for them, and 2) they would have far greater 
technology to be able to explore space and find us than we have.

Why has that not happened even though we have only been searching for 
others for 50 years? That remains unanswered even if you assume we have not 
been listening long enough, and assume that we are searching for signals in 
ways which are different from the ways in which the signals are being sent.

In 13+ billion years, there are a lot of opportunities to miss each other? 
That's incredibly silly. That also means there have been a lot of 
opportunities to notice each other even if just by chance.

One way to be sure you never hear from other civilizations is to not 
listen? That's illogical. If the other civilizations wish to make 
themselves known to us, they could get our attention regardless of our 
effort or ability to listen.

It is possible other civilizations exist, are capable of making themselves 
known to us, but do not CHOOSE to make themselves known to us. But without 
a valid reason to think that other civilizations would act differently than 
we act, there is no reason to think that all other existing civilizations 
would actively avoid making contact. And with the millions of other 
civilizations which SHOULD exist according to the Fermi paradox, it seems 
unlikely that all of them would choose not to reveal themselves to us even 
though we have not spent enough time or resources in trying to find them.﻿

comments.text:
It's easy to share in Bill's sense of adventure - he's an intelligent and 
enthralling person.  Unfortunately both he and Fermi fail to take 
faster-than-light travel into consideration for this paradox debate. Thanks 
to theoretical propulsion physicists like Harold White of NASA, and his 
recalculation of the Alcubierre drive, it's only a matter of time before 
humanity breaks through the FTL barrier ourselves.  Fermi's paradox is 
exponentially more supported once re-factored for intelligent beings able 
to move faster than the EM spectrum Bill mentioned we should search more 
of.  With the cosmos being about 13.7B years old, and allowing for about 5B 
years to have enough supernovas to distribute more complex elements 
necessary for complex life, as well as subtracting enough time for planet 
to form and support life (i.e. 4.5B years), we're left with 4.2 billion 
years in which some other intelligent life could have explored or colonized 
a significant portion of the universe using faster-than-light propulsion. 
 Just imagine where humans will be in 1000 years.  Or 10 thousand.  Or a

comments.text:
I want to believe there are intelligent civilizations out there.And that's 
the problem,I'm clearly biased.And I've learned enough that if you want to 
believe in something you should be very skeptical of it. I've come to know 
that somethings are counterintuitive,that we might just be alone;that at 
this point in time,we might be the first civilization to come about,or the 
last.Given the tremendous time,difficulties,resources and conditions it 
takes for intelligent life to form, and how quickly it can end,it's not 
that statistically pigheaded to assume that we might be indeed the only 
ones.I know many people don't like to even entertain this notion,because it 
smacks of Creationism,and gives credence to the anthropocentric belief that 
we Humans are indeed special.But like I alluded earlier,reality does not 
give a damn about our ideological preferences,it just is.And disavowing the 
possibility that we may be alone shows an incredible bias, you can't prove 
there are no aliens the same way you cannot disprove leprechauns;if you're 
going to state that there definitely are aliens out there because the 
universe is so big,you might as well say there might be leprechauns out 
there because the world is so big.

Granted,intelligent civilizations are statistically more probable than 
leprechauns,but I have not seen any proof to justify such claims,absence of 
proof is not proof of absence.I remain a skeptic on this subject,microbes 
on the other hand...anyways,I hope I'm wrong.﻿
